content.description: This climb has 3 bolts and a few small gear places.  The pitch is quite short.
content.protection: Three bolts and small gear placements to chain anchors visible from the ground.
content.location:
This is the 16th route down the line, to the right of

Billy's Harem

.  Look for the lowest set of chain anchors on the wall, climb goes up the gully/crack thing.

content.description: Trickle Down Theory climbs sustained steepness through the entire route with a crux about 1/3 of the way up through a bulge.
content.location:
It is the 4th route from the right side of wall between

Heart of Gold

and

Mother's Little Helper

.

content.description: Start from the top of the detached block with a two bolt anchor on it.  The crux of this route is at the very beginning.  3 pitches to the top then rap the same way you came.  I combined pitches 2 and 3 without any problems.
content.location: This is the farthest route left on the Main Wall.

climbs.name: Perturbation Theory
climbs.fa: Damon Johnston, Charlie Fowler, and Julie Hodson

content.description: Climb pockets and jugs.  This is a good route.
content.location: It is the 5th route from the left on the Main Wall.

content.description: Clip bolts up and past a diagonal crack to chains.  It is a good route.
content.location: This is the 6th route from the left on the Main Wall.

content.description:
Mother's Little Helper is very similar to

Trickle Down Theory

with sustained, steep climbing that is well bolted. This has two cruxes: the first is a blank section above the second bolt, and the second is the bulge above that.
content.location:
It is the 3rd route from the right of the wall between

Lobotomy

and

Trickle Down Theory

.

content.description: Mad Dog is a decent route.  This was my partner's first lead, and he said that the bolts were nicely spaced and would recommend it to other aspiring leaders.  It had plenty of jugs and great feet.
content.location: This is the 4th route from the left on the Main Wall.

content.description: This is the hard line on the Main Wall.  Start up a crimpy face which gradually gets steeper and then don't pump out through a set of back to back overhangs - the deceitful crux lying at the 2nd overhang.  After pulling through the 2nd roof, you are home free to the chains.  It is a very good pitch - worth investing some energy.
content.location: 21st climb down the wall.  This is on the orange wall and is the 2nd line of bolts from the right before the large nasty gigantic block.  The climb goes up the steepest part of the orange wall.

content.description:
This has really good climbing with great pockets all the way.  It shares the same crux and anchors as

Beta Decay

.
content.location: It is the 10th route from the left on the Main Wall.

content.description: This is a good warm up with big holds and pockets on relatively low angle rock.
content.location: It is the second route from the left on the Main Wall.

content.description: Climb to the right of a seam up to chains.  It is a nice route with good pockets.
content.location: This is the 7th route from the left on the Main Wall.

climbs.name: Heart of Gold
climbs.fa: P1: Charlie Fowler & James Stevens P2: Conrad Anker & Kevin Thaw

content.description:
A brilliant climb!

P1: Climb confidently up through the first few bolts with excellent movement on good holds, then move out left to the arete (crux) and continue up this spectacular arete to the first set of chains. This pitch is arguably the best on the wall with fun movement and very good rock. (5.11+)

P2: Continue up the face through a roof clipping bolts along the way. (5.10+)
content.protection: P1: Bolts to chains. P2: Bolts to chains.
content.location: This is the 18th route down the line.  Go down the small hill, and this will be the first climb to the left on the orange wall proper.  Start just right of an obvious arete, stay to the right, and eventually go out left to the arete up high.

content.description: This has sweet climbing past bolts to the chains.  Be confident at the grade, because the first bolt seemed high, and if you blew it while clipping the second, there would be groundfall potential.  The crux was probably between the first and second bolt.
content.location: It is the 8th route from the left on the Main Wall.

content.description: This climb is the direct and more difficult variation of Crystolopolis.  Face technically demanding footwork up the arete before you join up with Crystolopolis, and follow it all the way to the chains.  It is a good route.
content.location: This is a variation of the 11th route down the wall (start on the arete to the right of the Crystolopolis crack - look for the bolts).

content.description: This starts out fairly easy and then throws you into a sustained overhanging wall.  Big moves on big holds yield big fun, though there are plenty of holds in-between for the vertically challenged.  It is an excellent pitch of rock and (in my opinion) the classic climb of the grade on this wall.
content.location: The 12th route down the wall, located on its own face/arete type thing.

content.description: This is a fun route starting up a moderate face, then it goes through a big roof and up steep rock to the chains.  Watch out for bats! :)
content.location: This is the 15th line down the wall.

content.description: Fun climbing with the crux between the last bolt and the chains.  Shares an anchor with Knob In My Pocket to the right.
content.location: 9th route from the left on the Main Wall.

content.description: This is a cool route that arcs right up and over a large crack/roof.  I thought that this was the best 5.8 on the wall.
content.location: This is the third route from the left on the Main Wall.
